{{Infobox astronaut | name = Mike Melvill | image = patti-presenting-wings-web.jpg | caption = Melvill receiving the first [[commercial astronaut]] wings | type = [[Commercial Astronaut]]
[[File:US - FAA Astronaut Wings.png|150px]] | nationality = South African / American{{cn|reason=seems to be no source at all in the article on what his citizenship is; just where he was born and where he has lived for many years|date=December 2017}} | birth_name = Michael Winston Melvill | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1940|11|30}} | birth_place = [[Johannesburg]], South Africa | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = [[Test pilot]] | alma_mater = [[Hilton College (South Africa)|Hilton College]] | selection = [[List of astronauts by selection#2003|SpaceShipOne 2003]] | space_time = ~10 mins | missions = [[SpaceShipOne flight 15P]], [[SpaceShipOne flight 16P]] | insignia = }} '''Michael Winston "Mike" Melvill''' (born November 30, 1940 [[Johannesburg]] {{cite web|url=https://global.britannica.com/biography/Michael-Melvill|title=Michael Melvill - American pilot and astronaut|publisher=|accessdate=24 October 2017}}) is a world-record-breaking pilot{{cite web|title=Chronological listing of all known flights around the World |url=http://www.earthrounders.com/cgi/chrono.php |publisher=Earthrounders.com |accessdate=3 July 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120712175742/http://www.earthrounders.com/cgi/chrono.php |archivedate=12 July 2012 |df= }} and one of the [[test pilot]]s for [[SpaceShipOne]], the experimental [[spaceplane]] developed by [[Scaled Composites]]. Melvill piloted SpaceShipOne on its first flight past the [[edge of space]], [[SpaceShipOne flight 15P|flight 15P]] on June 21, 2004,{{cite web |url=http://www.scaled.com/projects/tierone/combined_white_knight_spaceshipone_flight_tests |title=Scaled Composites: combined white knight spaceshipone flight tests |publisher=Scaled.com |date= |accessdate=2010-08-02}} thus becoming the first [[commercial astronaut]] and the 434th person to go into space.{{cite web |url=http://www.worldspaceflight.com/bios/m/melvill-m.php |title=M.Melvill |publisher=Worldspaceflight.com |date= |accessdate=2010-08-02}} He was also the pilot on SpaceShipOne's [[SpaceShipOne flight 16P|flight 16P]], the first competitive flight in the [[Ansari X Prize]] competition.{{cite web |url=http://www.spacefacts.de/bios/astronauts/english/melvill_michael.htm |title=Astronaut Biography: Michael Melvill |publisher=Spacefacts.de |date= |accessdate=2010-08-02}} ==Life and career== In 1978, Melvill met aerospace designer and [[Scaled Composites]] founder [[Burt Rutan]] when he flew to California to show Rutan the [[Rutan VariViggen|VariViggen]] he had built at his home. Rutan then hired him on the spot. In 1982, he was named Rutan's lead test pilot.{{cite web |url=http://www.astronautix.com/astros/melvill.htm |title=Melvill |publisher=Astronautix.com |date= |accessdate=2010-08-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101020020000/http://astronautix.com/astros/melvill.htm |archivedate=2010-10-20 |df= }} In 1997, Melvill and [[Dick Rutan]], Burt's brother, flew two [[Rutan Long-EZ|Long-Eze]] aircraft that they built side-by-side around the world. This "around the world in 80 nights" flight was called The Spirit of [[Experimental Aircraft Association|EAA]] Friendship World Tour, and some legs of it lasted for over 14 hours.{{cite web|url=http://airportjournals.com/dick-rutan-the-frontiers-of-flight-the-last-great-world-record/|title=Dick Rutan The Frontiers of Flight – The Last Great World Record|date=10 October 2014|publisher=|accessdate=24 October 2017}} Later in his career he became Vice President/General Manager at [[Scaled Composites]]. ==Awards and achievements== [[File:Scott Crossfield, passes the torch of Space Travel to Mike Melville by D Ramey Logan.jpg|thumb| The first "Commercial Astronaut", Mike Melvill, reviews the first private space flight with [[Scott Crossfield]]]] Melvill is the sole or joint holder of nine [[Fédération Aéronautique Internationale|FAI]] aviation world records in various categories.{{cite web |url=http://records.fai.org/data?p=707 |title=History of Records: Michael W. MELVILL (USA) |publisher=records.fai.org |date= |accessdate=2010-08-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100729102740/http://records.fai.org/data?p=707 |archivedate=2010-07-29 |df= }} He was awarded the [[Iven C. Kincheloe Award]] in 1999 for high altitude, developmental flight-testing of the [[Scaled Composites Proteus|model 281 Proteus]] aircraft. Through [[SpaceShipOne flight 15P]] in 2004, he is known as the first privately funded [[human spaceflight]] mission pilot to reach space.{{cite web |url=http://www.flyincruisein.com/MMelvill.html |title=Mike Melvill |publisher=Flyincruisein.com |date=2004-06-21 |accessdate=2010-08-02}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * Biography at Scaled Composites http://www.scaled.com/projects/tierone/pilots/michael_w._melvill * [https://web.archive.org/web/20140719044635/http://www.earthrounders.com/cgi/melvill.php Sport Aviation article by Melvill describing his round-the-world trip] * [http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/5236958/ "First private space pilot 'ready to go'"], ''msnbc'', Alan Boyle, 6/21/2004, accessdate August 2, 2010 {{The Spaceship Company}} {{Scaled Composites}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Melvill, Michael W.}} [[Category:1940 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Johannesburg]] [[Category:South African people of British descent]] [[Category:Commercial astronauts]] [[Category:American aviators]] [[Category:South African astronauts]] [[Category:Scaled Composites]] [[Category:Scaled Composites Tier One program]] [[Category:Glider pilots]] [[Category:Aviation pioneers]] [[Category:Alumni of Hilton College (South Africa)]] [[Category:Alumni of Highbury Preparatory School]] [[Category:American test pilots]]
